question: What can I do for you, Officer?
answer: You know it is against the city ordinance to keep chickens or live stock.

question: I always had chickens, ducks and whatnots.
answer: Not anymore, not in the city.

question: We grow most of our own food. The money I get from social security, my pension and my wife's work, keeps us living on the edge. What choice do people like us have.
answer: Well, you just have to move further out.

question: Now how far would further out be?
answer: I'm not here to argue, sir.

question: Like what may I ask?
answer: Look, just get rid of the chickens and you all have a nice day.

question: Since when?
answer: Take Sunny home, please.

question: Your feet are cold.
answer: Go back to sleep.

question: I asked you to wake me when Babe Brother comes.
answer: You all act like two roosters.

question: I'm not going to let him get away with murder.
answer: You and Babe Brother are so much alike...

question: He ain't nothing like me. How come a man has to have sons that are day and night apart? You ought to stop protecting him.
answer: Hush.

question: You're always taking his side.
answer: Hush.

question: I'm trying to make him a man but you keep babying him.
answer: You're going to find yourself on the floor.

question: Son, if you are going to have a family, you can't always choose a job just because you like it. I don't want you to shine anybody's shoes or be a porter. You let somebody else carry your bags. He wouldn't want any if you didn't try to keep it away from him.
answer: Because you were spoiled, don't try to spoil Sunny.

question: My daddy never gave me anything without my having to sweat for it. Every summer, the way they kept me and Junior out of trouble was to send us to Big Daddy's farm. We would get up with the chickens. Every summer the fence had to be repaired. The barn needed a coat of paint. We had to pip all of Big Mama's hundred laying hens and go to church all day on Sunday. For Big Daddy, calluses and sweat were the mark of a man. Sunny will never have to bust his knuckles like we did.
answer: I want Sunny to have an advantage that you and I never had, but he needs discipline, and you are not helping when I tell him to do something and you allow him to get out of it.

question: What is a sip of coffee going to do?
answer: Coffee is bad for anybody, especially for a child.

question: I don't see you crying about my drinking it.
answer: How old are you?

question: You always got something to say.
answer: Your mother asked me not to mention it but your mother's birthday was last week.

question: I hadn't forgotten. I ordered some cloth but it didn't come in and I felt so bad if I would have come to her birthday without that, I just stayed at home.
answer: What did your wife get her?

question: We got the same thing.
answer: Boy, go tell your wife to come in.

question: What are you doing in these parts?
answer: I came all the way from Detroit by bus going to Oakland. The bus stopped in Los Angeles. I had to get off and take a rest. I'll catch the last bus leaving at midnight. I'm just too tired to go on.

question: Why didn't you catch a plane?
answer: My feet have never been on anything that wasn't directly attached to the ground.

question: Stay until you feel better? I would like to hear all the news.
answer: I'm worn out but won't you feel like you are taking in a stranger?

question: It's the boy next door throwing at his birds. I'm just waiting on him to hit a pane in the window
answer: I'm going to wash up now. You all please excuse me. Good morning.

question: You ought to come hear our preacher. Remember old Cat Iron? Well, our preacher is just as strong.
answer: Next time when I feel a little better perhaps.

question: I was going to get up and get a hen out there for dinner, but time got away.
answer: Oh, I would feel much at home if you let me get one for you. I haven't wrung a chicken's neck in a month of Sundays. You know, folks would call my daddy to kill their hogs. That used to be my trade from time to time.

question: You don't act like the rest of Gideon's friends. They believe if you are not hard at work, you are hard at sin.
answer: Oh, I'm more modern in my ways. I don't believe in sin, though there is good and evil. And evil is a thing you work at. Not you mustn't touch. Your mama might not like you handling knives.

question: I think he wants to see your rabbit foot.
answer: I let this rabbit foot do in place of my toby that I lost years ago.

question: What's a toby?
answer: You don't want to be at crossroads without one. It's a charm that old people teach you how to make. I had one for a long time that belonged to my grandmother who had it ever since she was a child. In my travels I misplaced it. I have been looking over my shoulder ever since.

question: I thought you weren't old fashioned.
answer: In some things. When we were children, there used to be an old man that came around and would snatch your soul if you didn't have something on you that didn't make a Did you have your child at home?

question: No. No. No. No. I had my Child at Cedars and Sinai. And that ain't no county hospital. You have to have cash or check before you come in the door.
answer: Some folks take that natural stuff too far.

question: Junior's wife kept her afterbirth' in the refrigerator. That's why I do not eat over there now.
answer: Country people got so many strange ways,

question: Country people got so many strange ways,
answer: Did you ever have to use this thing?

question: That is called a crab apple switch. It's for those bad acting monkeys and just the thing for a mean dog. Now I don't know if I actually did what I did or got my life and story mixed in with other folk's stories but I seem to recall that I had to use my crab apple on a boy from back home. I was up in Memphis working on the railroad, like your daddy who had an easy job. He would sing a song that had a cadence and we would lay track. Anyway I was coming down Beale Street and I heard this music coming from a saloon. Sure enough it was Emory. My daddy taught both of us to play but Emory was natural at it. Got in a blues band and what not. He and another boy had killed a boy named Hocker sometime back and they balled the Jack leaving town. Emory had lost one eye and had a scar running down his face. Bad luck I would say. He got to drinking that corn liquor. We went to his girl's room and he wouldn't stop drinking. He started talking about the old days and he went mad. He pulled his knife and I got to mine first. The lights went out.
answer: Don't pick up the cards if you are not in the game. Did he die?

question: How often is your wife called to help delivery?
answer: It was slow. Now it seems like everyone is having births at home. What could have caused this? I just changed this damn thing.

question: Everything these days is made overseas.
answer: You and Babe Brother hit it off so well.

question: Course, it is your business, but I feel obliged to tell you that maybe you have not been fair with the boy.
answer: I tried to teach him right from wrong just like I did his Junior.

question: Everyone has to follow his own plough. A man doesn't have to know how to cut a wick and clean a chimney nowadays. City people don't give a hoot and a holler about the shape of the moon nowadays. You don't plant old ways... ... but, at the end, you find yourself doing what your father did but you have to have the land in you. It's when you want to give the house or farm to the kids and they don't want it. You sell it to a stranger. You worked your whole life, for what? I doubt if people nowadays have knowledge of a victory garden or seen an inch worm. All what we've experienced has no meaning.
answer: You're suppose to teach your children what you know. Junior, I don't have to worry about. Babe Brother is a different story.

question: You still call him boy. You call Babe Brother boy in front of his wife and son.
answer: My daddy called me boy up to the time he died. I was always boy to him.

question: It has three bedrooms, one and a half baths. Well, yes, that means two toilets and one bath. Well... Yes, by appointment... Call me back if you decide. You would think people never lived in a house if they have to ask what does 1 1/2 baths mean.
answer: Will you still get the money from your father?

question: I told him we might not need it, if you can talk your parents into giving you your share of the property.
answer: Pops put Big Daddy's farm in Rhonda's and Sunny's name and fixed it so no one can borrow on it.

question: We could borrow on that land and put the money to work.
answer: I preached to Mom and Dad about it but they are stuck in their ways, it's like talking to a brick. But if there is a way...

question: I preached to Mom and Dad about it but they are stuck in their ways, it's like talking to a brick. But if there is a way...
answer: You want me to mortgage my house to invest in a scheme of yours? You know the last time we went into something together Daddy had to go in his savings to keep us from ending on the street.

question: Why are you always afraid to get somewhere?
answer: This is not a good time to take chances. Your best friend, Robert, an accountant, lost his home and is out on the street. We see him from time to time. He comes down to church for a free meal.

question: This is what it is all about, trying to keep from being out on the street.
answer: Robert asks about you. When are you going to do something to help him?

question: Maybe I can get down there next week.
answer: Babe Brother always acts like a gambler who is in the biggest game of his life and don't know about playing cards.

question: It hasn't been the years; it's been the men in her life.
answer: Harry, that's not nice. I'm in church now.

question: Why run out and close the barn door when the horse is gone? I remember when you weren't saved. That was way back yonder when the Natchez Trace was just a dirt road.
answer: Some people grow up and change their ways.

question: I know your mother ain't still operating that house of hers.
answer: My mother passed on years ago.

question: I haven't heard anyone mention Swamp Root since button-up shoes went out.
answer: You can certainly tell how old you are, my dear.

question: You know the saying, "your heart is in your left hand."
answer: Now I was trying to be nice, to make conversation, since we go back some.

question: I was quoting from the Bible. If the shoe fits, wear it.
answer: "Out of weariness, I spoke to my own heart; to leave it all and to die. And I gave my heart to know madness and folly."

question: A woman in family way just reminds of spring and my younger days.
answer: That's nice.

question: Well, you and your husband are special. Ya, Gideon tells me you do volunteer work to help feed the poor. How many people do you all feed?
answer: Last Saturday we handed out over two hundred meals.

question: Good God Almighty, bless your bones. But the problem grows.
answer: Week by week the crowds at the door keeps getting larger. We can't feed all the hungry.

question: Of course not. Have you ever heard of a man jumping in the river to save five hundred drowning people? No you ain't. You have to take just one and fatten him up. When you spread help too thin, you , you just nickel and dime the situation. If you try to save all, all die but if you save one life, life goes on. You just have to remember, medicine that works leaves a bitter taste. You just take one; you thaw out the cold and hunger in his bones from sleeping on the bare ground.
answer: I don't know if we could take one in with Rhonda and me at home alone at times.

question: Oh, I wasn't pointing my finger at you. Hey, you have to think of yourself. A lot of them have all kinds of diseases and will cut your throat while you sleep. There are too many bad people out there.
answer: I appreciate you lending me a hand. That lazy ass brother of mine was suppose to help me.

question: Well some folks are still waiting for their comeuppance. Don't take me wrong but you can't judge people by how you act. You're a caring person.
answer: He should be caring. That is not too much to ask.

question: Ya, but you can't do the shuffle with one leg. You and your wife, in your spare time, work with the less fortunate. Now I'm not talking about you and what you do but some folks that always run to help the victim, deep down are attracted to pain and suffering and love to be near the dying.
answer: All the people working with us are really doing it 'cause they hate to see suffering.

question: You never know what's in the heart and just because you can cry doesn't make you human.
answer: We can't really bring another family in here with us.

question: Son, you haven't danced with your wife all night.
answer: There is something that I always wanted to know. Tell me, how did those boys die?

question: Now who are we talking about?
answer: Miss Clara's boy, Emory, to start with. The Johnson's Hocker was another one...

question: Wasn't Hocker lynched?
answer: You know as well as I do that it was made to look like he was lynched. Now who would hang someone from a persimmon tree?

question: Is that the way your parents raised you?
answer: Why, you don't want us to bring him over?

question: No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.
answer: Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.

question: Junior spends time with his child.
answer: Oh here we go with that.

question: Do you want your coat? It's cold out here.
answer: No, I'm too hot now.

question: You better be careful. You'll get a stroke arguing.
answer: I wouldn't care if I drop dead if he learn something from it. Son, you make me wish I was dead.

question: I think if anybody had a hand in killing Hocker, you ought to ask or you should have asked Emory and Chick.
answer: Chick was outright killed by a mob. He killed a white man that owed him some money and when they caught up with him, they tied him behind a car and dragged him from out of the hills back to town.

question: Those boys never did have good luck.
answer: You damn right they didn't, especially Emory, my cousin.

question: I'm worn out.
answer: Just stay in bed and rest.

question: I have to feed the chickens before they wake everybody up.
answer: You stay inside. I will see to them.

question: Ah, you young folks don't know how it is. How is Gideon today?
answer: He wasn't able to get out of bed today.

question: I hope that it's nothing serious.
answer: He has never gotten rid of the malaria. He is usually up and at it the next day. I'm going to make him fresh chicken broth.

question: Let me earn my keep. I'll go out and get a hen and have it picked and ready for the pot. Try to make him some cow tea next time.
answer: Can you watch Gideon for a while? One of the girls is going into labor. Junior is going to drive me over.

question: You just run along. I'll fix him his soup. He will be all right.
answer: Oh my Lord!

question: It's good to be able to hear that.
answer: You must have been really sick.

question: How is the garden doing?
answer: I need to get out there and get those weeds out.

question: Sister, we've come to see how you were doing. We came to ask if we could pray over Gideon.
answer: I put some Plummer Christian Leaves under his feet to draw the fever out.

question: What else have you been giving him?
answer: I crossed his stomach with cold oil and gave him some cow tea.

question: Suzie, I would think you would depend on prayer rather than these old fashion remedies. Let us read from the Bible.
answer: I don't know where that music is coming from.

question: Rhonda, drag him in here. If you be nice, I will take you to Disneyland.
answer: Now you don't have to say anything if you don't want to.

question: I want to hear what happened. My brother is a jackass and a damn fool. The both of you have been as scarce as hen's teeth.
answer: Rhonda, take Sunny in the backyard. Take a bowl so you can pick some strawberries. Sunny will enjoy it. You shouldn't talk about the boy's father in front of him. This is family business and we have to pull together.

question: No, this was an accident.
answer: Sure.

question: It was unintentional.
answer: Babe Brother reminds me of the story of the man who wanted to be sizable. He wanted to be tall but what he was really short on was brains. There was a time when people had moon fever were treated with leeches. It's that nut of yours.

question: What are you doing?
answer: Counting the gray hairs in your head.

question: Counting the what? What does that have to do with the price of butter?
answer: I was just trying to make conversation.

question: Where is Skip?
answer: He is in his pigeon cage.

question: I'm sorry he got those birds.
answer: You know the man next door is near death. He must have gotten rid of those chickens. You don't hear them crowing anymore... I kind of miss it now.

question: I brought you these greens and some salt meat.
answer: That is very thoughtful of you. I haven't had time to tend to my garden like I should.

question: You know Gideon and I are lodge brothers and it has always been a policy to take care of the wives if something happens to our brother.
answer: You are very sweet, but Gideon has already taken care of everything in case something happens to him. He has a policy.

question: If you become a widow, you will need someone around to fix the whatnots. We like for the widow to marry someone in the lodge. I know Gideon ain't gone yet, but there will be a lot of his old friends coming around to get in line. I just want you to consider this as a kind of a conditional proposal, to be first in line so to speak.
answer: Excuse me. I have to go feed my dog.

question: You know Harry lied about how that boy Hocker got kilt. And it was Harry who saw Emory last before they found him hanging over a levee like someone would hang a hog.
answer: I remember Harry always trying to help someone. He got Lulla's daughter out of trouble. He was always running to the store for someone who couldn't leave the house.

question: Harry always shows his good side and, like the moon, the other side is black. Back home he always did try to act like the colored gentleman. I'm telling you Harry is nothing but evil. I'm warning you -- you can't keep a wild animal as a pet around children.
answer: You know Okra asked me to marry him the other evening.

question: Rush your mouth, girl. No, he didn't. He cannot be that big of a damn fool.
answer: I asked Harry about it. He didn't own up to it. He said he didn't know what got into Okra.

question: He's just raffish. Harry put him up to it. Before evening sun sets, I would have his belongings back on Route 55, that old fox.
answer: I can't accuse him just dry long

question: Everybody who have been associated with Harry end up with pennies over their eyes.
answer: What must I do?

question: As God is my witness, I have never done anything to that woman.
answer: You must have done something to her.

question: Since she has repented, all she does is throw stones.
answer: Hattie is a different person now.

question: I don't make no bones about where I'm going to spend eternity. I have always been wild and you know that. If you are made to feel half a man, what do you think the other half is?
answer: I'm glad you brought that up as to who you are. I have to know who is in my house.

question: You invited me.
answer: Only if you are a good man, a friend. Are you a friend?

question: Like that boy next door playing that his horn. If he was a friend, he would stop irritating people, but if he stops practicing, he wouldn't be perfect in what he does someday.
answer: I want you to leave.

question: I don't want to wear out welcome, but you can stay in someone's heart longer than you can stay in their house. Come with us, boy. We are going to have a good time.
answer: This would be a bad time for me to leave.

question: We are going where the action is. Ain't that right, Okra? Let's play for a couple of bucks unless you want to start off with two bits and work our way up. What would you give to be rich?
answer: Had Moms and Pops given me my share of what was mine, I could have been rich by now. Linda and I had it all worked out.

question: I need to get my suitcase out of the garage.
answer: What for?

question: I'm going back home with Harry.
answer: I've heard some foolish things in my life.

question: Harry is coming to pick me up.
answer: Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.

question: I'm busy.
answer: Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.

question: Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.
answer: I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough. You sit right there with your no manners self.

question: Where is Babe Brother?
answer: Brother is in the kitchen.

question: How come you didn't ask Babe Brother to help you?
answer: He said he was busy. He is mad 'cause he wanted to get in the garage to get his things so he could go with Harry.

question: Why in the hell didn't you help mama?
answer: I told her I would if she would give me time.

question: I bet you if your master would have told you to fix the hole in the roof, you would have rebuilt the whole damn house.
answer: You always got the best of it around here and when Dad always talks about my son, it is always you, so you fix the roof.

question: That is a damn lie and you know it. Every time father asks you to do something, you either half-ass do it or run off and hide. Mama asked you to turn the dirt in her garden and you told her, with your smart ass self, that you weren't a farmer; get Junior to do it. Every time someone asks you to do something, you always say, tell Junior to do it. Boy, you ought to grow up.
answer: I told you about calling me boy. I ain't no boy. See, you and Dad got a bad habit of calling me boy. You call me boy in front of my wife. You think I'm going to fix the roof? I hope the wind blows the whole damn thing off and it pours down rain.

question: How long has he been dead?
answer: Since this morning.

question: What happened to your hand?
answer: I cut it on an old rusty knife.

question: What did you put on it?
answer: It's healing now.

question: I hope you will take care of your mother better than that when I'm gone. Babe Brother, is that my shirt that you're wearing?
answer: Yes.

question: How come you're not wearing my shoes?
answer: They're too big.

question: I have more sense than to give up everything, my family, you and Sunny. It wasn't me, I mean the real me inside my body. I'm glad it's over. It's like a veil has been lifted.
answer: Like a veil has been lifted?

question: It's like I've been swimming in muddy waters.
answer: Like muddy waters?

question: It was like all those things old country people try to tell you what hell is like.
answer: You were in hell?

question: I couldn't believe the things I was doing. It was like an internal struggle going on inside my body.
answer: Do you think you won?

question: It was nip and tuck.
answer: And what lesson have we learned from all of this, Babe Br... Sam... I mean Samuel?

question: It feels like a storm has passed... Hattie read some of Harry's letters to a woman he had a child by. The child had died and he was writing to give her some comfort. Hattie didn't know that deep down at the bottom of Harry's hate, there was some love.
answer: Did I ever tell you the story about the man who wanted to make his own mind up about heaven and hell? He didn't want nobody's opinion but his own. He's going to check out heaven first. He gets a round trip ticket to heaven. He gets in heaven and finds it just like back home. People dripping with sweat, working in the fields, hardly surviving. He asked a man who was getting a drink of water, "I thought the streets were paved with gold." "They are but you won't see them," he said. "Boy, you got to work day and night cause idleness is sinfulness." So he takes the other half of his ticket and takes the express to hell. He sees people stretched out on their backs kicking back, picking their teeth. "Man, this is a dream." He asked, "What's you'll doing?" They all hollered back, "Sinning." The devil was shaking hands with everyone and came up to him and said, "Please to meet you." He asked, "I thought you'll was supposed to be burning in fire." Someone said, "Man, ain't no fire down here except under that pot of chitlins." The man was going go ask the preacher back on earth...

question: I don't want to hear any joke about colored people being in hell. You're being irreverent.
answer: I'm almost finished. I'm about to come to the punch line.

question: I don't want to hear any tales about colored people...
answer: But these are white people, anybody. The punch...

question: I don't care to hear any jokes about people being in hell. This cut on my hand reminds me that it is nothing to laugh at.
answer: It's only a tale.
